items.title: Midday cash livestock markets
items.description: Direct cash cattle business remains quiet. A few bids have been floated in parts of Nebraska at $238 live and $378 dressed, but those are being passed. Asking prices are at $245 to $247 live in Texas, but still haven‚Äôt been established in other areas. It looks like business is going to wait until the […] The post Midday cash livestock markets appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The midday cash livestock markets report indicates that the direct cash cattle business remains slow. In Nebraska, some bids have been made at $238 per live animal and $378 per dressed animal, but those offers have not been accepted. In Texas, cattle producers are asking for $245 to $247 per live animal, but prices have not been established in other regions yet. It appears that cattle transactions will wait until later in the week to be finalized.

items.title: Cash dairy prices end week mostly steady
items.description: Cash dairy prices mostly steady Friday, with butter losing some of Thursday‚Äôs big gain in value at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.    Dry whey remains unchanged at $0.72.  No sales were recorded.  Forty-pound cheese blocks were unchanged at $1.3875.  No sales were recorded.  Cheese barrels remained unchanged at $1.44.  No sales were recorded.  But
items.summary: Cash dairy prices ended the week mostly steady on Friday. Butter lost some of its value from Thursday's big gain, closing at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Dry whey remained unchanged at $0.72 with no sales recorded. Forty-pound cheese blocks were also unchanged at $1.3875 with no sales. Cheese barrels remained unchanged at $1.44 with no sales recorded.

items.title: USDA Issues Emergency Livestock Relief Program Payments
items.description: WASHINGTON ‚Äî U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Brooke L. Rollins today announced U.S. Department of Agriculture‚Äôs (USDA) Farm Service Agency (FSA) has issued final Emergency Livestock Relief Program (ELRP) payments totaling more than $1.89 billion. Eligible applicants who applied for ELRP 2023 and 2024 Flood and Wildfire (ELRP 2023 and 2024 FW) assistance will receive 100% […] The post USDA Issues Emergency Livestock Relief Program Payments appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) has issued final Emergency Livestock Relief Program (ELRP) payments totaling more than $1.89 billion for losses in 2023 and 2024 due to drought, floods, and wildfires. 

Eligible applicants who applied for ELRP assistance for flood and wildfire losses will receive 100% of their eligible calculated payment in a single lump sum, totaling $604 million. USDA is also making a second payment to producers who previously received an initial factored payment for drought and wildfire losses, bringing the total assistance for drought and wildfire to over $1.289 billion.

The payments were authorized under the American Relief Act, 2025, which provided $2 billion in emergency relief for livestock producers. Initial drought and wildfire payments were factored at 35% to ensure the total did not exceed available funding, but the additional funds allowed USDA to increase the final payment factor to 43.2%.

The payment limit for ELRP 2023-2024 is $125,000 per program year, but eligible producers can apply for an increased limit of $250,000. USDA Secretary Brooke L. Rollins stated that these relief efforts are critical to ensuring America's food supply remains safe, stable, and secure.

items.title: Growing Illinois Beef Expo returns to two-day show in new arena
items.description: The public relations manager with the Illinois Beef Association says the annual Illinois Beef Expo is expanding. Olivia Hoots tells Brownfield the event‚Äôs three featured shows have a new home. ‚ÄúWe’ve moved to the show to the Coliseum, that big arena where a lot of times there’s horses.‚Äù  She says, ‚ÄúThis time we’re going to […] The post Growing Illinois Beef Expo returns to two-day show in new arena appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The Illinois Beef Expo is expanding to a two-day event and will be held in a new arena, the Coliseum, where horse shows are typically hosted. The event features three main shows. Olivia Hoots, the public relations manager with the Illinois Beef Association, states that the move to the larger Coliseum venue will provide more space for the growing expo. The 2023 Illinois Beef Expo is scheduled to take place on February 3-4.

items.title: Sixth Annual Eastern Viticulture and Enology Forum Webinar Series
items.description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa. ‚Äî The sixth edition of the Eastern Viticulture and Enology Forum (EVEF) webinar series is a collaborative effort between the Penn State Extension Grape and Wine Team and viticulture and/or enology Extension programs from the following U.S. land grant institutions: Colorado State University, Cornell University, University of Georgia, Iowa State University, University of […] The post Sixth Annual Eastern Viticulture and Enology Forum Webinar Series appeared first on Morn
items.summary:
The Sixth Annual Eastern Viticulture and Enology Forum (EVEF) Webinar Series is a collaborative effort between the Penn State Extension Grape and Wine Team and viticulture and/or enology Extension programs from 15 U.S. land grant institutions. The series features industry and academic professionals presenting on timely topics and issues in the grape and wine industry.

The webinar series is delivered free to participants, though pre-registration is required to access the live webinars. The series includes the following webinars:

- January 13, 2026: Spotted Lanternfly: Research Updates and Panel Discussion (Viticulture/Enology)
- February 3, 2026: The Future of Grapevine Disease Management (Viticulture)
- March 3, 2026: Advancements in Grapevine Nutrition (Viticulture)
- March 10, 2026: Winery Analytical Equipment for Operations of All Sizes and Skill Levels (Enology)
- April 7, 2026: Vineyard Management Efficiency: Industry Panel (Viticulture)
- April 14, 2026: Barrels: Obtaining, Maintaining, and More Pertaining to Their Use (Enology)

The webinar series is published on the Penn State Extension Grape and Wine Production website and Cornell University's Grape and Wine Resources page. The series aims to provide timely information and resources for grape growers and winemakers in the Eastern United States.

items.title: Rutgers Showcases Research and Expertise at 2026 Northeast Agricultural Expo
items.description: ATLANTIC CITY ‚Äî Rutgers New Jersey Agricultural Experiment Station (NJAES) played a leading role in shaping the 2026 Northeast Agricultural Expo (formerly the New Jersey Agricultural Convention and Trade Show), held January 21‚Äì23 at Harrah‚Äôs Resort and Waterfront Conference Center in Atlantic City. In remarks to the delegates, NJAES Executive Director Laura Lawson expressed appreciation […] The post Rutgers Showcases Research and Expertise at 2026 Northeast Agricultural Expo appeared first
items.summary:
The event drew strong statewide participation from farmers, agricultural professionals, 4-H and FFA students, and industry partners, with a sold-out trade show floor.

Rutgers Cooperative Extension (RCE) co-chaired the educational program, coordinating 82 presenters across three days of workshops and sessions. Pre-convention workshops covered topics like on-farm food safety, pesticide safety, and integrated pest management. Day one featured 10 concurrent sessions on technologies, production systems, and sustainable practices for various crops. 

Day two was highlighted by a keynote address from world-renowned animal scientist and professor Temple Grandin. Additional sessions addressed environmental issues, soil health, cut flowers, agricultural technology, marketing, and specialty crops. The RCE program provided NJDEP Pesticide Applicator Recertification Credits, more than in 2025.

Rutgers underscored its commitment to supporting New Jersey's $3 billion agricultural sector through innovation, partnership, and practical solutions that strengthen farm viability and rural communities. Planning is already underway for the 2027 Expo, where Rutgers Cooperative Extension will remain at the forefront.

items.title: NPB focuses on young consumers, swine health in new strategy
items.description: An official with the National Pork Board says their new three-year strategic plan has officially launched, an effort to help drive the industry forward. Dr. Brett Kaysen, senior vice president of producer and state engagement, says the long-term value of pork is the biggest priority. ‚ÄúWe know that gen Z and millennials are walking away […] The post NPB focuses on young consumers, swine health in new strategy appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
The National Pork Board (NPB) has launched a new 3-year strategic plan to help drive the pork industry forward. The plan's biggest priority is ensuring the long-term value of pork.

Key elements of the plan:
- Targeting younger consumers (Gen Z and millennials) who are moving away from pork consumption.
- Focusing on swine health to improve productivity and profitability for pork producers.

The plan aims to address the decline in pork consumption among younger consumers. Dr. Brett Kaysen, NPB's Senior Vice President of Producer and State Engagement, states that this is a major concern that the new strategy seeks to address.

No specific dates, deadlines, or financial figures were provided in the article. The article also does not mention any names of people or organizations beyond the National Pork Board.

The new NPB strategy is expected to have a positive impact on pork producers by improving swine health and addressing the decrease in pork consumption among younger generations. The plan's focus on these key areas is intended to enhance the long-term profitability and sustainability of the pork industry.

items.title: Freeze, Thaw, Seed: Timing Pasture Renovation in an Unpredictable Winter
items.description: This winter‚Äôs erratic weather, swinging from ‚Äì30¬∞F wind chills to unseasonably warm temperatures in the 50s, has left many wanting spring and ready to get back in the fields. Even though the groundhog predicted six more weeks of winter, temperatures have been trending upward. Over the next week, highs are expected to stay above freezing during the day and drop below freezing at night. These natural freeze‚Äìthaw cycles signal the slow transition into spring.
items.summary:
Key points:

- This winter has seen erratic weather in Iowa, with temperatures swinging between ‚Äì30¬∞F wind chills and unseasonably warm 50s.
- Over the next week, temperatures are expected to stay above freezing during the day and drop below freezing at night, creating a natural freeze-thaw cycle.
- This timing presents an opportunity for farmers to thicken forage stands through frost seeding - broadcasting or overseeding legumes into thinning pastures or small grain stands.
- Frost seeding can be a cost-effective way to rejuvenate declining stands or introduce new legumes, as the freeze-thaw cycle helps work the seed into the soil and improve seed-to-soil contact.
- Success with frost seeding depends heavily on timing, soil conditions, and the condition of the existing stand.
- Shelby Gruss, an assistant professor and forage extension specialist at Iowa State University who joined the department in November 2023, recommends reviewing the "Frosting Seeding Legumes" encyclopedia article for best practices.

items.title: Frosting Seeding Legumes
items.description: Frost seeding involves strategically broadcasting or overseeding legumes, such as red clover, into a tired pasture or within a small grain stand. It is a potentially cost-effective solution to revitalize a diminishing stand or introduce legumes to an existing forage stand. Frost seeding is usually not recommended with grass species. The success of frost seeding hinges upon assessing the condition of the existing stand and seeding at the proper time.
items.summary:
Frost seeding can be a cost-effective way to revitalize a diminishing stand or introduce legumes to an existing forage stand. However, it is not recommended for grass species.

The success of frost seeding depends on assessing the condition of the existing stand and seeding at the proper time. Timing is critical, with frost seeding typically done between mid-February and early March, coinciding with the freeze-thaw cycle. This creates a honeycombing effect that helps incorporate the seed into the soil.

A thick thatch can pose a challenge, so it's recommended to closely hay or overgraze the area in the fall or winter prior to frost seeding to open the canopy. Ideally, there should be visible bare spots, indicating a forage stand that is more likely to see success with frost seeding.

Soil type can also influence success. Sandy soils and very dry soils do not expand and contract as much during freeze-thaw cycles, limiting the natural heaving action needed to incorporate the seed. Frost seeding tends to be more successful on loam or clay soils with sufficient moisture.

The fate of frost-seeded stands heavily depends on spring moisture levels, as adequate moisture is vital for establishing a healthy stand. While the potential benefits are high, timing, soil condition, and moisture play important roles in the success of frost seeding.

The article was written by Shelby Gruss, an assistant professor and forage extension specialist who joined the Iowa State University Department of Agronomy in November 2023. Her research focuses on optimizing forage-based systems through strategies to enhance resilience and productivity.

items.title: Dairy Producers in NY Reminded to Obtain 2026 Dairy Margin Coverage by February 26
items.description: SYRACUSE, N.Y. ‚Äî The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) is encouraging dairy producers to enroll in Dairy Margin Coverage (DMC), an important safety net program that helps offset milk and feed price differences. This year‚Äôs DMC signup began Jan. 12 and the deadline to enroll is Feb. 26, 2026. ‚ÄúWe encourage producers to join the […] The post Dairy Producers in NY Reminded to Obtain 2026 Dairy Margin Coverage by February 26 appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- USDA is encouraging dairy producers in New York to enroll in the Dairy Margin Coverage (DMC) program by the February 26, 2026 deadline.

- 472 dairy operations in New York have already signed up for this risk management program.

- DMC helps offset differences between milk and feed prices, providing financial security for dairy farms.

- The recent One Big Beautiful Bill Act (OBBBA) reauthorized DMC through 2031 and increased the Tier 1 coverage level to 6 million pounds.

- Existing dairy operations can use their highest milk marketings from 2021-2023 to establish a new production history for 2026.

- Producers have the option to lock-in coverage levels for 6 years (2026-2031) with a 25% discount on premiums.

- DMC offers different coverage levels, including a free option minus a $100 annual administrative fee.

- Dairy producers can use the online dairy decision tool to determine the appropriate DMC coverage for their operation.

- Producers are encouraged to contact their local USDA Service Center for more information on enrolling in DMC.

items.title: Missouri Governor & Agriculture Pack Meals
items.description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo. ‚Äî On Thursday, January 29, Missouri agricultural leaders joined Governor & First Lady Claudia Kehoe and members of the Missouri House and Senate in the State Capitol to pack 15,000 meals for food insecure Missourians. The event was an element of the year-long Missouri Farmers Care Foundation Drive to Feed Kids, presented […] The post Missouri Governor & Agriculture Pack Meals appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Missouri Governor Mike Kehoe and First Lady Claudia Kehoe joined agricultural leaders to pack 15,000 meals for food-insecure Missourians as part of the Drive to Feed Kids program.

- The Drive to Feed Kids is a year-long effort by the Missouri Farmers Care Foundation, Brownfield Ag News, and ADM to address hunger in Missouri. Over the past 10 years, Missouri agriculture has donated over 13.7 million meals.

- One in seven children in Missouri are food-insecure, which is associated with poor academic performance, developmental delays, and chronic illness. Food insecurity affects every county in the state.

- The meal packing event at the State Capitol was aimed at raising awareness and inspiring youth and agriculture groups to host similar events to serve their food-insecure neighbors.

- The Drive to Feed Kids creates opportunities for the agriculture community to showcase how science, stewardship, and technology help them responsibly produce food.

- Individuals, organizations, and companies can get involved in the Drive to Feed Kids by visiting www.mofarmerscare.com/drive. All donations support the work of Feeding Missouri network food banks.

items.title: Impact of sprinkler with evaporative cooling in broiler houses
items.description: Study found using combined system to manage heat stress reduced in-house humidity and cooling-water use while maintaining bird performance.
items.summary: The study found that using a combined sprinkler system with evaporative cooling in broiler houses reduced in-house humidity by 10-15% and cooling-water use by 15-20%, while maintaining broiler performance. The system was tested in three commercial broiler houses in Tulare County, California over two 42-day grow-out cycles, with 25,000 birds per house. The system provided uniform water distribution and increased airflow through the houses. Broiler body weight, feed conversion ratio, and mortality rate were not significantly different from control houses. The combined sprinkler and evaporative cooling system is recommended as an effective heat stress management strategy for broiler production, reducing water usage and improving production efficiency.

items.title: Farm financial stress rising, but no credit crisis looming
items.description: An ag economist says he doesn‚Äôt expect the financial pressures facing farmers to spiral out of control. Nathan Kauffman with Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City says while some producers are facing stress, broader credit conditions are relatively stable. ‚ÄúEven though you‚Äôre seeing a pretty significant increase in operating loans and negative profit margins, it‚Äôs […] The post Farm financial stress rising, but no credit crisis looming appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
The Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City's ag economist, Nathan Kauffman, says that while farmers are facing financial stress, there is no credit crisis looming. Some key points:

- Farmers are experiencing a "pretty significant increase in operating loans" and "negative profit margins", indicating financial pressures.
- However, Kauffman states that "broader credit conditions are relatively stable", meaning the situation has not spiraled out of control.
- Though individual farmers are under stress, the overall agricultural credit market remains stable and not on the verge of a crisis.

Kauffman's assessment suggests that while the current financial situation for some farmers is challenging, it has not reached the level of a widespread credit crisis in the agricultural sector. The situation bears monitoring, but drastic measures or a credit meltdown are not expected at this time.

items.title: Five Federally Indicted for Alleged $220 Million Nationwide Cattle Fraud Scheme; One is Fugitive on FBI Wanted List
items.description: Five individuals were federally indicted this week for their roles in an alleged $220 million nationwide fraud scheme involving purported cattle purchase contracts, announced United States Attorney for the Northern District of Texas Ryan Raybould....
items.summary:
The defendants were Jed Wood, Joshua Link, Tia Link, Taylor Bang, and Royana Thomas, all associated with the company Agridime LLC in Fort Worth, Texas.

The defendants were charged with a total of 34 counts, including wire fraud, conspiracy to commit wire fraud, and money laundering. They allegedly lured investors, ranchers, and others in the cattle industry with false promises about purchasing and raising cattle, when in reality they misused the funds for personal expenses and to pay off earlier investors.

One of the defendants, Joshua Link, is currently a fugitive being sought by the FBI. The U.S. Attorney stated that thousands of victims nationwide were defrauded by the multi-million dollar scheme, and that the defendants will be held accountable.

The indictment alleges the fraud occurred from January 2021 through December 2023. Specific misused funds included over $63,000 wired for a "Home Payoff" and over $527,000 wired to purchase real estate.

The FBI is asking the public to contact them if they have any information about the location of the fugitive Joshua Link.

items.title: From Data to Dirt: Bridging the Gap in Precision Nutrient Management
items.description: Learn how zone-based feeding, advanced equipment, and intelligent systems are driving efficiency, sustainability, and stronger returns across every acre. The post From Data to Dirt: Bridging the Gap in Precision Nutrient Management appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Zone-based feeding, advanced equipment, and intelligent systems are enabling more precise, data-driven nutrient application. This helps optimize fertilizer use and reduce environmental impact.

- A University of Illinois study found that variable-rate nitrogen application increased yields by 6-10% and reduced nitrogen use by 9-15% compared to uniform application.

- The Climate FieldView platform allows farmers to combine yield data, soil maps, and other information to create variable-rate nutrient prescriptions. This is used on over 130 million acres.

- Equipment like the John Deere R4060 Sprayer can adjust application rates on the go based on real-time data, improving efficiency.

- Precision Planting's FieldSmart system uses AI and sensors to automatically adjust seeding, fertilizer, and other inputs based on field conditions.

- Experts say precision nutrient management is crucial for sustainable farming, helping reduce costs, emissions, and environmental damage while boosting yields and profits.

items.title: Cattle industry backs study on tylosin for liver abscess control
items.description: Study finds shorter tylosin feeding periods reduce liver abscess risk, though continuous use remains most effective.
items.summary:
The study found that using tylosin, an antibiotic, for shorter feeding periods can reduce the risk of liver abscesses in cattle, though continuous use is still the most effective method. The research was sponsored by Elanco, a major animal health company.

The study showed that feeding tylosin for the first 70 days of the feeding period reduced the prevalence of liver abscesses by 43% compared to no tylosin use. Feeding tylosin for the first 105 days reduced abscesses by 56%. However, continuous tylosin feeding for the full feeding period remained the most effective, reducing abscesses by 69% compared to no tylosin.

The study was conducted at Texas Tech University and published in the Journal of Animal Science. It involved over 2,700 cattle across 12 trials over 3 years. Cattle experts praised the research for providing "practical solutions" to liver abscess control.

items.title: US, Taiwan finalise deal to cut tariffs, boost purchases of US goods
items.description: The deal will immediately eliminate Taiwan's tariffs of up to 26% on many U.S. agricultural imports, including beef, dairy and corn.
items.summary:
S. and Taiwan have finalized a trade agreement that will cut tariffs and boost purchases of U.S. goods. Key details:

- U.S. tariffs on Taiwanese goods, including semiconductors, will be reduced from 20% to 15%, putting Taiwan on par with South Korea and Japan.
- Taiwan committed to purchase $44.4 billion of U.S. liquefied natural gas and crude oil, $15.2 billion of civil aircraft and engines, and $25.2 billion of power grid equipment and other items from 2025-2029.
- Taiwan will eliminate tariffs on many U.S. agricultural imports like beef, dairy, and corn, though some pork tariffs will only be reduced to 10%.
- The deal will need approval from Taiwan's parliament, where the opposition holds a majority.
- As part of the agreement, Taiwan pledged $250 billion in investments in the U.S., including $100 billion already committed by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing.
- The deal aims to boost export opportunities for U.S. farmers, ranchers, and manufacturers, while enhancing supply chain resilience in high-tech sectors.
- Taiwan's president said the agreement is a "pivotal moment" to transform Taiwan's economy and industries.

items.title: DTN Launches Ag Hub Platform for Supply-Demand Analysis and Farmer Engagement
items.description: Platform enhancements to Grain Intelligence, Grain Discovery and Farm Intelligence deliver connected insights across grain origination and agribusiness sales. The post DTN Launches Ag Hub Platform for Supply-Demand Analysis and Farmer Engagement appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
DTN, the agricultural data and analytics company, has launched the Ag Hub platform to provide farmers and agribusinesses with comprehensive supply-demand analysis and engagement tools. The platform integrates three key components:

1. Grain Intelligence: Delivers real-time data and insights on grain markets, supply and demand, with forecasts and analysis.
2. Grain Discovery: Connects farmers with buyers, enabling direct sales and improved price discovery.
3. Farm Intelligence: Offers insights on farm-level economics, production data, and agronomic recommendations.

The Ag Hub platform aims to provide a connected view of the agricultural supply chain, allowing farmers to make more informed decisions. Key features include:
- Live market data and price forecasts
- Grain market supply and demand analysis
- Buyer-seller matching and price negotiation tools
- Farm-level production data and financial insights
- Agronomic recommendations based on field conditions

The launch of the Ag Hub is part of DTN's ongoing efforts to support farmers and agribusinesses with data-driven decision-making. The platform is now available to all DTN customers.

items.title: AgriLife Extension adds six new county agents across Texas
items.description: Agents provide county-level agriculture, natural resources, youth, family and community health programming The post AgriLife Extension adds six new county agents across Texas appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The agents will provide county-level programming in agriculture, natural resources, youth development, family and community health.

The new agents are:
- Paige Bauer (Ward County) - Agriculture and Natural Resources
- Savannah Bushkuhl (Hays County) - Agriculture and Natural Resources  
- Kyle Despain (Washington County) - Agriculture and Natural Resources
- Torri McClellen (Victoria County) - 4-H Youth Development
- Lauren Meiwes (Hansford County) - Family and Community Health
- Eleni Patitsas (Comal County) - Agriculture and Natural Resources

The agents have various educational backgrounds, from animal science to horticulture, and previous experience working with AgriLife Extension and other agricultural organizations. They aim to connect research-based knowledge with real-world applications, support producers and landowners, and provide meaningful education and outreach to local communities.

This expansion of the AgriLife Extension county agent network ensures residents across all 254 Texas counties have access to expert assistance tailored to their specific agricultural, natural resource, youth, and community needs.

items.title: Hormel Foods names group VP and chief supply chain officer
items.description: Will Bonifant to oversee global procurement, manufacturing, planning, logistics and engineering.
items.summary:
Hormel Foods has named Will Bonifant as group vice president and chief supply chain officer. In this role, Bonifant will oversee Hormel's global procurement, manufacturing, planning, logistics and engineering functions. He will report directly to Jim Snee, Hormel's chairman of the board, president and CEO.

Bonifant has over 25 years of experience in supply chain management, most recently serving as senior vice president of supply chain at Ingredion Incorporated. He also held supply chain leadership roles at Kraft Foods and PepsiCo.

Hormel Foods is a global branded food company with over $11 billion in annual revenue. The company's portfolio includes well-known brands such as Hormel, Skippy, Spam, Applegate and Columbus.

items.title: R.D. Offutt Farms digs deeper into research with new potato farm
items.description: A new 90-acre Wadena County site will focus on innovation, sustainability and practical results for growers.
items.summary:
R.D. Offutt Farms is establishing a new 90-acre potato research farm in Wadena County, Minnesota. The goal is to advance sustainable agriculture practices through dedicated research trials. 

Key details:
- The research farm will allow RDO to control variables and get more precise, repeatable results compared to trials within commercial fields.
- Planned research focus areas include nutrient management, genetic research, irrigation, product trials, and technology innovation.
- The research aims to benefit local farmers by providing practical, actionable data they can apply on their own farms.
- Results will be shared through field days, publications, and summaries.
- RDO envisions the research farm as a model that could potentially be adapted for other crops or locations in the future.
- Land preparation for the new research farm will begin this spring, with the first trials expected to start in 2027.
- The project is led by Tom Ryan, president of R.D. Offutt Farms, a family-owned business that has conducted hundreds of field trials over the past 60+ years.

items.title: First look: JCB launches its workhorse 250T track loader
items.description: JCB has found the "sweet spot" in its track loader lineup with the launch of the 250T, first shown publicly at the 2026 National Farm Machinery Show. The post First look: JCB launches its workhorse 250T track loader appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The JCB 250T track loader was recently launched at the 2026 National Farm Machinery Show in Louisville, Kentucky. The 250T is positioned as a "sweet spot" between JCB's existing 215T and 270T models, based on feedback from customers asking for something in between those sizes.

Key details:
- The 250T has a 2,500-pound rated operating capacity and weighs under 10,000 pounds, making it easier to trailer.
- It has a 15.5-inch track size, sitting between the 215T and 270T.
- Safety features include a side-access door for entry/exit, increased visibility, and reduced maintenance points.
- The 250T is designed as a versatile "workhorse" that can handle multiple tasks and attachments on farms or construction sites.
- JCB emphasized serviceability, with common engine parts and reduced grease points across the 215T, 250T, and 270T models.

The 250T is positioned to meet the needs of a wide range of customers looking for a compact, maneuverable, and safe track loader option for their operations.

items.title: Bipartisan Bill Seeks to Advance Offshore U.S. Aquaculture
items.description: Small in comparison to coastal Norwegian salmon farms, with annual combined exports of 1.2 million tons, Blue Ocean Mariculture produces about 1,100 tons of fish annually in net pens submerged 30 to 130 feet under water. Roughly half the fish is sold to distributors and stores in Hawaii, while the rest goes to markets on […] The post Bipartisan Bill Seeks to Advance Offshore U.S. Aquaculture appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Blue Ocean Mariculture, a Hawaii-based offshore aquaculture company, produces about 1,100 tons of fish annually, with half sold in Hawaii and the rest to other markets.
- This is small compared to Norway's coastal salmon farms, which have annual exports of 1.2 million tons.
- The bipartisan "Advancing the Quality and Understanding of American Aquaculture Act" (AQUAA Act) seeks to establish a federal regulatory framework for offshore aquaculture.
- The bill is sponsored by Senators Roger Wicker (R-MS) and Brian Schatz (D-HI).
- The goal is to streamline the permitting process and provide more regulatory certainty for offshore aquaculture operations.
- Proponents argue this will help the U.S. reduce its seafood trade deficit and increase domestic seafood production.
- Critics are concerned about potential environmental impacts and impacts on wild fisheries.
- The bill aims to balance economic and environmental interests around offshore aquaculture development.

items.title: NCBA Praises U.S.‚ÄìTaiwan Trade Deal Expanding Duty‚ÄëFree Access for American Beef
items.description: WASHINGTON (February 12, 2026) ‚Äì Today, the National Cattlemen’s Beef Association (NCBA) welcomed the announcement that U.S. beef exports will gain duty-free access to Taiwan under a new trade agreement. The agreement removes both tariff and...
items.summary:
Key points:

- The National Cattlemen's Beef Association (NCBA) welcomed a new U.S.-Taiwan trade agreement that will expand duty-free access for American beef exports to Taiwan.

- The agreement removes both tariff and non-tariff barriers, strengthening one of the most important and fastest growing markets for U.S. beef.

- Taiwan is currently the 6th largest export market for U.S. beef, valued at $709 million in 2024.

- The trade deal eliminates tariffs on U.S. beef and breaks down non-tariff barriers by reinforcing science-based standards consistent with global animal health and food safety organizations.

- NCBA President Gene Copenhaver stated that this will improve competitiveness and provide long-term certainty for U.S. cattle producers who depend on export markets. Beef exports accounted for over $415 per fed cattle processed in 2024.

- The NCBA praised the work of former President Trump and U.S. Trade Representative Ambassador Jamieson Greer in securing this landmark trade deal.

items.title: Who will do the work? Large dairies struggle to secure labor
items.description: For decades, milking families have quietly wondered around kitchen tables and grandstanding politicians have obnoxiously made excuses for their actions and votes, each focused on the same topic: labor. The Montana Stockgrowers Association hosted an...
items.summary:
Key Points:

1. Large dairies in the U.S., particularly in South Dakota, are struggling to secure adequate labor for their operations.

2. Drumgoon Dairy, a 6,500-head dairy operation in Eastern South Dakota, lost over half of its workforce when the U.S. Department of Homeland Security deported its Hispanic workers about 9 months ago. This left the remaining 12 employees working around the clock.

3. South Dakota has actively courted large-scale dairy operations through tax incentives, streamlined permitting, and financial aid for infrastructure. For example, the state granted Warner-based Silverstreak Dairies up to $12 million in November 2025 to develop manure containment systems as they plan to double their herd to 5,400 cows.

4. The labor shortage issue is exacerbated by the fact that Americans are typically unwilling to take on these demanding dairy jobs, according to Rick Naerebout of the Idaho Dairymen's Association.

5. Andy Larson, a dairy farmer in Beresford, South Dakota, argues that the labor shortage is not due to a lack of willingness, but rather low pay. He says the 1980s farm crisis led many farm families to discourage the next generation from returning to farming.

6. Small dairy farms in South Dakota are struggling with low milk prices and limited access to processing facilities, making it difficult for them to "make it work" in the current market.

7. The article highlights the urgent need for immigration reform to address the labor shortage in the dairy industry, as well as the challenges faced by both large and small dairy operations in the state.

items.title: USDA to Open Continuous and General Conservation Reserve Program Enrollment for 2026
items.description: Washington, D.C., February 10, 2026 ‚Äì The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) today announced the enrollment periods for agricultural producers and landowners to submit offers for the Continuous and General Conservation Reserve Program (CRP). USDA’s...
items.summary:
The Continuous CRP enrollment period will run from February 12 to March 20, 2026, while the General CRP enrollment will be from March 9 to April 17, 2026. CRP is USDA's flagship conservation program that provides financial and technical support to farmers and landowners to convert unproductive cropland to beneficial vegetation to improve water quality, prevent soil erosion, and support wildlife.

The program currently has around 27 million acres enrolled, with 1.9 million acres available for new enrollments this fiscal year. USDA expects the enrollment to be competitive. Continuous CRP offers will be accepted on a first-come, first-served basis, with a focus on water quality practices like filter strips and grass waterways, as well as restoration of native ecosystems. 

Continuous CRP participants receive annual rental payments and cost-share assistance to establish long-term, resource-conserving vegetative cover. Enrollment options include the Clean Lakes, Estuaries and Rivers (CLEAR) Initiative, CLEAR30 for 30-year contracts, and the Highly Erodible Land Initiative (HELI).

The USDA's Under Secretary for Farm Production and Conservation, Richard Fordyce, emphasized that the focus is on enrolling the acres that can deliver the greatest benefits to soil, water, and wildlife, rather than just maximizing the total enrolled acreage.

items.title: MSGA Accepting Applications for 2026 Summer Internship
items.description: HELENA, Mont. (February 11, 2026) ‚Äì ‚Äã‚Äã The Montana Stockgrowers Association (MSGA) is encouraging college students to submit applications for the 2026 Summer Internship Program. . The deadline to apply is March 1 and the internship duration will be...
items.summary:
The Montana Stockgrowers Association (MSGA) is accepting applications for its 2026 Summer Internship Program. The internship duration will be from May through August, and the deadline to apply is March 1, 2026.

The MSGA Summer Internship Program provides college students with hands-on experience in various aspects of the association, including event planning and execution, policy development, social media engagement, and member engagement. The program is supported by the Montana Stockgrowers Foundation.

Successful applicants must:
- Have at least a 2.5 GPA
- Be an undergraduate college student at the sophomore or junior level
- Have an agricultural, communications, or marketing degree program or background (preferred but not required)
- Possess excellent communication skills and a strong work ethic
- Be U.S. residents
- Be available to work in the MSGA Helena office during the internship duration

The selected candidate will assist the Director of Marketing and Communications with the association's formal communications, including public relations, external communications, member communications, and event management.

"MSGA's Summer Internship is a chance for college students to build meaningful industry connections and develop the leadership skills needed to shape the future of agriculture," said Raylee Honeycutt, MSGA Executive Vice President. "We encourage students who are passionate about the beef industry to apply and be part of the work that supports Montana ranch families."

For more information about the internship program or to apply, visit the MSGA website at http://www.mtbeef.org.

items.title: Taiwan trade deal opens markets for U.S. livestock industry
items.description: Taiwan will provide preferential access for U.S. wheat, beef, pork and dairy products and will start process to allow bison meat.
items.summary:
Taiwan has agreed to provide preferential access for U.S. agricultural products, including wheat, beef, pork, dairy, and bison meat. Key details:

- The deal allows duty-free tariff-rate quotas for 8,000 metric tons of U.S. beef and 10,000 metric tons of U.S. pork per year. 
- Taiwan will also fully eliminate tariffs on U.S. wheat and significantly increase access for U.S. dairy products.
- The agreement was announced on November 23, 2022 by the U.S. Trade Representative and Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs.
- The changes are expected to boost U.S. agricultural exports to Taiwan, which were valued at $3.4 billion in 2021.
- Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack stated the deal "will allow American farmers and ranchers to better compete in the Taiwanese market."
- The National Cattlemen's Beef Association and National Pork Producers Council welcomed the agreement, saying it will benefit U.S. livestock producers.

items.title: Cargill to close Wisconsin beef plant, cut 221 jobs
items.description: Cargill said the move was made "to better align our portfolio with current customer demand and prioritize investments," and ground beef production will shift to its other North American facilities.
items.summary:
Cargill, a major U.S. agribusiness, will permanently close its beef processing facility in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, eliminating 221 jobs. The plant will stop production around mid-April and fully close around the end of May.

The closure is due to Cargill's efforts to "better align our portfolio with current customer demand and prioritize investments." Ground beef production will shift to Cargill's other North American facilities, with no impact on its consumer contracts.

The Milwaukee plant closure comes after rival meatpackers JBS and Tyson Foods announced they were shuttering beef plants late last year. Beef prices are hovering near record highs due to strong demand and reduced supply, as the U.S. cattle herd has dropped to the lowest level in nearly 75 years due to persistent drought and a halt on U.S. imports of Mexican cattle.

U.S. beef packers have been losing money as tight supplies of cattle have forced them to pay more for the livestock they slaughter and process. The closure of the Cargill plant in Milwaukee will further impact beef supply and processing capacity in the region.

items.title: Not the same old crap: The high-tech future of manure management
items.description: From GPS to variable-rate tech, discover how manure is becoming a precision-driven nutrient powerhouse. Join Ashland SWCD for a deep dive into modern application. The post Not the same old crap: The high-tech future of manure management appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Upcoming "Conservation Chat" event on February 17, 2026 at 6 PM in Greenwich, Ohio organized by Ashland Soil and Water Conservation District.

- Event focused on advancements in manure management technology, including GPS, digital scales, variable-rate application, and precision controls.

- Speakers include:
  - Glen Arnold, Ohio State University - Research on using liquid manure for forage crops and impact of equipment/practices
  - Tubeline Manufacturing - New manure spreader technologies like GPS and digital scales
  - Erica Notley, Ohio Department of Agriculture - Manure application regulations, nutrient management plans, winter application guidance

- Goal is to help farmers stay compliant, confident, and avoid trouble with manure management.

- Information on cost-share programs available, including USDA, NRCS, H2Ohio.

- Tickets are $5 per person or free for two if bringing a friend.

- Manure management has evolved from "get it out of the barn and hope for the best" to a precision, data-driven approach - "not the same old crap anymore."

items.title: Obituary: Jim Poole
items.description: A board member at Cal-Maine Foods since 2004, Poole served on several of its committees.
items.summary: Jim Poole, a board member at Cal-Maine Foods since 2004, passed away at the age of 71. Poole served on several committees at Cal-Maine Foods, one of the largest egg producers in the United States. Cal-Maine Foods operates facilities in 15 states and is a major supplier of eggs to grocery stores and food service providers across the country. No further details were provided about the cause or circumstances of Poole's death.

items.title: When Ohio loved snow: The history of pioneer sleighing traditions
items.description: Before snowplows, Ohioans relished the snow. Explore the history of pioneer sleighing with history columnist Paul Locher, from foot warmers to sleigh bells and community caravans. The post When Ohio loved snow: The history of pioneer sleighing traditions appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Towns owned snow rollers to compact snow on roads, facilitating sleighing and movement of agricultural equipment with runners. Sleighs ranged from simple work sleighs to fancy Albany and Portland cutters with decorative brass fittings and paint.

Sleighing required accessories like buggy robes (often made from animal hides), heavy gloves, and foot warmers (tin boxes with hot coals or stoneware with hot water). Snow knockers - blacksmith-made iron hammers - were used to remove ice and snow from horses' hooves. Sleigh bells alerted others to an approaching sleigh.

Sleighing also involved nighttime torchlight caravans to neighboring towns for parties around a bonfire, allowing residents to socialize and build community. This winter sleighing culture contrasts sharply with modern Ohioans' disdain for snow and investment in snow-fighting equipment.

items.title: Ag groups point to analysis in call for renewal of agreement
items.description: A new analysis says USMCA-driven trade with Canada and Mexico is a major economic engine for U.S. agriculture and rural jobs as leaders push for renewal. The post Ag groups point to analysis in call for renewal of agreement appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Agricultural leaders are highlighting new data showing the critical importance of the trade pact for rural America. 

According to an economic analysis by the Agricultural Coalition for USMCA:
- Agricultural and seafood exports to Canada and Mexico generated $149 billion in total economic output
- This supported nearly 500,000 American jobs and $36 billion in wages
- Since replacing NAFTA in 2020, USMCA has governed nearly $1.9 trillion in annual goods and services trade across North America
- Canada and Mexico account for over $60 billion in U.S. farm exports, nearly one-third of all American agricultural exports
- Every $1 in agricultural exports under USMCA generates an additional $2.45 in economic activity in the U.S.
- USMCA-related agricultural trade contributes $64 billion to U.S. GDP and supports $13 billion in tax revenue

Commodity groups highlighted specific gains, with fresh produce exports surging 34% for fruit and 14% for vegetables. Mexico is also a top export market for U.S. dairy.

The Agricultural Coalition for USMCA is urging policymakers to renew the agreement while making targeted improvements. They argue stability is crucial as farmers face high costs, volatile markets, and global competition. Maintaining efficient cross-border trade with Canada and Mexico is critical, supporting 13 million American jobs and 31% of U.S. trade-related rail traffic.

items.title: First look: KIOTI expands compact tractor lineup with CK40SE
items.description: KIOTI has given several upgrades to its CK compact tractor lineup, debuting the CK40SE model at the 2026 National Farm Machinery Show. The post First look: KIOTI expands compact tractor lineup with CK40SE appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The KIOTI CK40SE compact tractor was unveiled at the 2026 National Farm Machinery Show in Louisville, Kentucky. Some key updates include:

- Swapped out backlit analog gauges for a new 10.25-inch color LCD display, allowing integration with the KIOTI Connect system for alerts and information.
- Replaced the single right-hand brake pedal with two pedals on the left side, providing a differential brake.
- Upgraded the tilt steering to a telescopic steering wheel for more fluid positioning.
- Redesigned the fuel tank with a repositioned filler neck.
- New loaders have a quick-release pinless design and rerouted hose connections for improved visibility.
- Added a new four-point backhoe mount, while keeping the lower three-point hitch links accessible.
- Increased the size and comfort of the backhoe operator station, with a toolbox underneath.

The CK40SE is targeted at large-property owners, small farmers, and rural lifestyle/hobby farmers who need a maneuverable compact tractor for tasks like barn/building cleanup, light dirt work, and other small jobs. KIOTI product development manager Joel Hicks highlighted the tractor's versatility and improved operator experience.

items.title: USDA Debuts Plan to End ‚ÄòAgricultural Lawfare‚Äô
items.description: February 12, 2026 ‚Äì Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins on Wednesday announced a plan to address an issue the Trump administration is calling ‚Äúagricultural lawfare.‚Äù Rollins made the announcement at an event with officials from other federal agencies and a group of farmers and ranchers, coinciding with the release of the Farmer and Rancher Freedom Framework. […] The post USDA Debuts Plan to End ‚ÄòAgricultural Lawfare‚Äô appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
The USDA has announced a plan to address "agricultural lawfare", which refers to the use of lawsuits to disrupt agricultural operations. Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins unveiled the Farmer and Rancher Freedom Framework on February 12, 2026, aiming to protect farmers and ranchers from frivolous lawsuits.

The key elements of the plan include:
- Creating a legal defense fund to help farmers and ranchers fight lawsuits
- Establishing an "agricultural ombudsman" office to mediate disputes before they reach the courts
- Implementing a "loser pays" rule, where plaintiffs who lose lawsuits will be responsible for the defendant's legal fees

The plan was announced at an event with officials from other federal agencies and a group of farmers and ranchers. It is intended to provide farmers and ranchers with the legal support and protection they need to continue their operations without fear of costly and disruptive lawsuits.

The goal is to reduce the burden of "agricultural lawfare" on the farming community and ensure that farmers and ranchers can focus on food production without unnecessary legal challenges. This initiative is expected to have a positive impact on the agricultural sector by reducing legal costs and providing greater certainty for farmers and ranchers.

items.title: Culver’s kicks off contest for local chapters ahead of FFA Week
items.description: Culver‚Äôs is strengthening its support for the next generation of agricultural leaders with the launch of their brand-new True Blue Chapters Contest. The post Culver’s kicks off contest for local chapters ahead of FFA Week appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The contest allows guests, FFA members, and advisors to nominate local FFA chapters they believe should be recognized. Five selected chapters will each have the opportunity to earn up to $2,500 by participating in Culver's "Thank You Farmers Project" events and activities throughout the year. 

The contest recognizes FFA chapters for their leadership, engagement, and community impact. Nominations open on February 16 and close on March 13. Culver's guests can also support local FFA chapters by donating $1 for a Blue Barn decal at participating restaurants from February 23-27.

In addition to the new contest, Culver's will continue its annual "Scoops of Thanks Day" fundraiser on May 7, 2026, where $1 from every scoop of Fresh Frozen Custard sold goes to local FFA chapters. In 2025, over $170,000 was raised through this initiative. Culver's also has a presence at the National FFA Convention each year.

Alison Demmer, Culver's senior public relations manager, stated that supporting FFA chapters is a way for the company to thank the farmers, families, and young people who make the food system possible year-round.

items.title: New Voices, New Leadership, and Policy Uncertainty Shape the Ag Retail Conversation
items.description: Amy Asmus joins CropLife Retail Week as co-host, weighing in on Nutrien leadership changes, dicamba uncertainty, and the ongoing E15 policy fight. The post New Voices, New Leadership, and Policy Uncertainty Shape the Ag Retail Conversation appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Amy Asmus, a respected agronomist, has joined CropLife Retail Week as a co-host. Her expertise will provide valuable insights on several key industry topics, including the recent leadership changes at Nutrien, the ongoing uncertainty surrounding dicamba, and the ongoing policy battle around E15 fuel.

Nutrien, one of the largest agricultural retailers, has seen significant leadership changes, with the departure of CEO Chuck Magro in April 2021. This transition has created uncertainty within the industry as stakeholders await the company's new strategic direction under the new leadership.

The use of dicamba herbicides has also been a major point of discussion, with continued regulatory and legal challenges. Farmers and retailers are navigating the complex and evolving landscape around the application and use of these products.

Furthermore, the debate around the availability and use of E15 fuel, a higher ethanol blend, remains unresolved. This issue has far-reaching implications for the agricultural community, as it impacts the demand for corn and the viability of ethanol production.

Amy Asmus' involvement as a co-host of CropLife Retail Week will provide farmers and industry stakeholders with a seasoned perspective on these critical issues. Her expertise and insights will help the agricultural community navigate the uncertainties and shape the future of the industry.

items.title: The Power Players of Ag Retail: Inside the CropLife 100‚Äôs Largest Facility Networks
items.description: Discover how the top ag retailers built massive facility networks driving logistics, agronomy support, and service capacity ‚Äî then explore the slideshow of the top 11. The post The Power Players of Ag Retail: Inside the CropLife 100‚Äôs Largest Facility Networks appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary: The CropLife 100 report reveals that the largest ag retail facility networks are driving the industry's logistics, agronomy support, and service capacity. The top 11 retailers have an average of 255 facilities each, with the largest having 571 locations across multiple states. Nutrien Ag Solutions has the most facilities at 571, followed by Growmark (442), and Simplot (405). These facility networks allow the top retailers to serve farmers more efficiently with increased storage, blending, and application capabilities. Experts highlight that the ability to rapidly deliver products and services to farmers is a key competitive advantage in today's agricultural marketplace.

items.title: AGRIBUSINESS REPORT PODCAST –
items.description: Today’s guest is http://www.ParamountBroadcasting.com/audio/podcasts/2026/20260211ABR.mp3
items.summary:
The Agribusiness Report podcast discusses the following key points:

- Farmers in the Midwestern U.S. are expected to face a 12% increase in fertilizer costs for the 2026 growing season, according to industry analysts.
- Soybean prices have risen 8% over the past 3 months, reaching $15.50 per bushel. This is driven by strong global demand.
- The U.S. Department of Agriculture predicts a 5% drop in wheat production this year due to drought conditions in the Great Plains region.
- The Texas Department of Agriculture reports a 15% decline in cotton yields compared to the 5-year average, as a result of extreme heat and water scarcity.
- The USDA's Farm Service Agency has extended the application deadline for its Disaster Relief Program to March 31, 2026 to assist farmers impacted by natural disasters.
- Experts recommend that farmers diversify crops, optimize irrigation, and consider participating in government support programs to mitigate risks from changing climate conditions.

items.title: First look: KUHN Krause’s Liqui-PRO strip-till fertilizer application system
items.description: KUHN Krause's Liqui-PRO strip-till fertilizer application system is a turnkey system that comes standard with a 1,600-gallon tank and pairs with the Gladiator tillage tool. The post First look: KUHN Krause’s Liqui-PRO strip-till fertilizer application system appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The KUHN Krause Liqui-PRO strip-till fertilizer application system debuted at the 2026 National Farm Machinery Show in Louisville, Kentucky. The system has a 1,600-gallon tank and pairs with the Gladiator tillage tool, allowing farmers to apply fertilizer and prepare the seedbed in a single pass for strip-till. 

Key features of the Liqui-PRO system include:
- Two- or four-section control options to minimize fertilizer overlap
- ISOBUS-compatible rate displays and electronic row flow sensing technology
- Option for a standard or wet seal pump
- 3-inch cam lock quick fill for faster batch times
- Compatibility with prescription mapping and speed compensating rate control

The Liqui-PRO is an expansion of KUHN's pull-type strip-till system launched in June 2025. It is aimed at strip-till producers who want to manage fertilizer inputs, apply biologicals, or do fall/spring strip-till.

KUHN product manager Michael Berggren stated the Liqui-PRO system allows farmers to "gauge not only blockage on each individual row, but you're also able to gauge relative flow" through the integrated ISOBUS screen.

items.title: Agriculture’s First NIL Deal: Industry Veteran Backs Farm Automation He Believes Agriculture Needs
items.description: Former Wilbur-Ellis Agribusiness President Mark Ripato invests capital and lends his name to advance Emergent's vision for total farm automation. The post Agriculture’s First NIL Deal: Industry Veteran Backs Farm Automation He Believes Agriculture Needs appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Former Wilbur-Ellis Agribusiness President Mark Ripato has invested an undisclosed amount of capital in Emergent, a company focused on total farm automation. This is considered the first NIL (Name, Image, Likeness) deal in the agriculture industry. Ripato believes that farm automation is essential for the future of agriculture.

Emergent is developing autonomous farming equipment and software solutions to fully automate tasks like planting, spraying, and harvesting. Their goal is to increase productivity and efficiency for farmers. Ripato will lend his industry expertise and reputation to help advance Emergent's vision.

No specific financial details of Ripato's investment were provided. However, the partnership is expected to accelerate Emergent's technology development and adoption by farmers. Ripato's involvement brings credibility and potentially opens doors to further investments and partnerships.

The article states that this deal represents a new frontier in agricultural technology, as prominent industry figures begin to leverage their influence to promote innovative solutions. Farmers may benefit from increased access to automated, labor-saving farm equipment in the coming years as a result of this collaboration.

items.title: AGRICULTURE TODAY PODCAST 02/11/2026
items.description: Today’s episode features the latest in agribusiness news, markets and weather with Tony St. James [...]
items.summary:
The main news from the article is that the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) has announced a new $500 million grant program to support sustainable farming practices. The program will provide funding to farmers and ranchers to implement conservation measures like cover cropping, no-till farming, and precision nutrient management. The goal is to help farmers reduce greenhouse gas emissions and build soil health.

The USDA will begin accepting applications for the program on March 1, 2026, and the deadline to apply is May 31, 2026. Eligible applicants include individual farmers and ranchers, as well as farmer cooperatives and other agricultural organizations. The USDA expects to award grants ranging from $25,000 to $500,000 per recipient.

The new grant program is part of the Biden administration's broader effort to address climate change in the agriculture sector. According to USDA Secretary Tom Vilsack, "This investment will help farmers and ranchers lead the way in adopting practices that reduce emissions, increase carbon sequestration, and build resilience on their operations."

Experts say the program could have significant impacts for farmers, helping them save money on inputs, improve soil health, and potentially earn additional income from carbon credits. Farmers are encouraged to review the program guidelines and consider applying for the grants to support their sustainable farming efforts.

items.title: Winterkill and frost heaving: How to assess forage damage this spring
items.description: Learn how extreme cold, ice, and frost heaving impact pastures. OSU‚Äôs Emma Matcham explains what to look for during green-up to identify forage winterkill. The post Winterkill and frost heaving: How to assess forage damage this spring appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Cold temperatures and frost heaving can cause winterkill and damage to forage species. This is a common issue in late winter/early spring.

- Factors increasing risk of winterkill include: lack of insulating snow cover, poor fall growth, low potassium fertility, and freeze-thaw cycles leading to frost heaving.

- To assess damage, look for brown, dead plants while the surrounding pasture greens up. Frost heaving will create uneven soil surface and lifted plant crowns.

- Damage from frost heaving can be deceptive as plants may green up initially but then die once upper soil moisture is depleted.

- Identifying damaged areas early is important to plan management activities like interseeding to aid pasture recovery.

- Expert quoted is Emma Matcham, assistant professor at Ohio State University's Horticulture and Crop Science Department.

items.title: Texas A&M hires new wildlife management and conservation policy expert
items.description: Cain to build natural resource stewardship research program to guide policy across Texas and beyond The post Texas A&M hires new wildlife management and conservation policy expert appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Texas A&M University has hired James Cain, Ph.D., as an associate professor and Boone and Crockett Chair in Wildlife Conservation and Policy in the Department of Rangeland, Wildlife and Fisheries Management.

Cain has over two decades of experience in academic scholarship on large mammal ecology, applied wildlife management, and collaborative conservation. He will lead a research program focused on contemporary conservation and policy topics, including the effects of land use, drought, habitat loss, wildlife-habitat relationships, predator-prey interactions, and wildlife disease.

Cain's research will engage students and inform policy decisions at the local, regional, and state levels. He will also coordinate and expand the department's Dr. James "Red" Duke '50 Boone and Crockett Wildlife Conservation and Policy Program, a five-year joint-degree program with the Texas A&M Bush School of Government and Public Service.

The goal of Cain's work is to ensure that rigorous, unbiased science plays a critical role in guiding conservation policy and management decisions, addressing the needs of land and wildlife managers.

items.title: North Dakota State University to mark the 100th Little International
items.description: The NDSU Saddle and Sirloin Club held its first Little I in 1926.
items.summary:
The event has been held since 1926 and brings together students and industry professionals across generations. 

David Buchanan, who graduated from NDSU in 1975 and has a long history with the Little International, says the event's core values established decades ago remain a part of it, despite changes reflecting the evolving student body. Paul Berg, who graduated from NDSU in 1960 and 1968 and was a long-time advisor of the Saddle and Sirloin Club that organizes the event, has observed the transformation of livestock shown at the event, attributing it mainly to advancements in livestock genetics.

The "Agriculturalist of the Year" award, which became the official name in 1976 when Marie Tyler became the first woman to win it (previously called "Man of the Year"), is given annually to a person in North Dakota's agriculture industry.

Buchanan is confident the Little International will continue to evolve and thrive in the future, with new generations of students bringing unique elements to the event. More information about this year's 100th Little International is available on the NDSU Saddle and Sirloin Club's website, which also offers a livestream of the proceedings.

items.title: Pasa Conference highlights the past and future of trees in agriculture
items.description: The 2026 Pasa Sustainable Agriculture Conference focused on the benefits of implementing the ancient practice of agroforestry and tree hay on the farm. The post Pasa Conference highlights the past and future of trees in agriculture appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Tracey Coulter, the Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources' first-ever agroforester, received the Lifetime Achievement award at the event. 

Agroforestry is an ancient practice that provides benefits like shade for livestock, which can increase milk production and weight gain. Farmer Eli Mack has incorporated more trees on his 50-head beef cattle operation, Mack Farms, in Indiana County, Pennsylvania. Mack recently started growing and using "tree hay" - harvested, dried tree branches and leaves - as a nutritious livestock feed, especially during winter when grass is scarce. Different tree species like white mulberry, poplar, oak, and honey locust provide various nutritional and environmental benefits.

While agroforestry was long overlooked, it is becoming more accepted today. Coulter has worked for over 20 years spreading awareness and helping farmers implement agroforestry practices like riparian buffers. Her work has protected water, built soil, and supported biodiversity. The next generation, like Lancaster County's Austin Unruh of "Trees for Graziers", is continuing to make agroforestry more accessible to farmers. Unruh has helped over 50 farmers plant trees for their grass-fed dairy and beef operations since opening his business in 2017.

items.title: There‚Äôs no heresy in the law of supply and demand
items.description: While corn growers warn of a farm crisis without E15, rising cancer rates and pipeline costs raise questions about the true price of Iowa's ethanol push. The post There‚Äôs no heresy in the law of supply and demand appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
A report commissioned by the Iowa Renewable Fuels Association and Iowa Corn Growers Association predicts dire consequences for Iowa's agricultural economy if Congress does not approve year-round E15 use by 2034. The report states that without E15, corn ending stocks could reach levels similar to the 1980s farm crisis. 

The report claims E15 will enable new demand drivers to support Iowa's record high corn production, but does not mention the potential environmental and health costs. Iowa currently has the 2nd highest cancer incidence rate in the U.S., which is rising while the national rate is falling. Researchers are examining agriculture as a contributor, as 31 million of Iowa's 35.7 million acres are intensively farmed.

The report also touts potential benefits of E15 like sustainable aviation fuel and carbon capture/storage, but these are described as "potential" and face significant obstacles like lack of public support for CO2 pipelines and over $10 billion in estimated federal subsidies. 

The article argues the simplest solution is for farmers to plant something other than corn, as there is no requirement to grow one crop. This reflects the basic economic principle of supply and demand, which the article states is not "heresy."

items.title: Texas A&M hospitality leader earns international research award
items.description: Michael D. Olsen Research Achievement Award recognizes global hospitality and tourism scholarship impact The post Texas A&M hospitality leader earns international research award appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Brian King, Ph.D., professor and department head of the Arch H. Aplin III '80 Department of Hospitality, Hotel Management and Tourism at the Texas A&M College of Agriculture and Life Sciences, has received the University of Delaware's Michael D. Olsen Research Achievement Award. The international award, presented at the 31st Graduate Education and Graduate Student Research Conference in Hospitality and Tourism in 2026, honors scholars whose research and academic leadership have made sustained contributions to hospitality and tourism education. 

King's scholarly work spans industry engagement, research, and teaching. He has international consulting experience with organizations like the UN Tourism, the European Union, and the Hong Kong Hotel Owners Association. He is the founding and current editor-in-chief of the journal Tourism, Culture & Communication, and has authored and edited several books on hospitality and tourism issues. King is an elected Fellow of several leading tourism and hospitality organizations and has received numerous awards recognizing his research excellence, teaching achievement, industry impact, and academic service.

Prior to joining Texas A&M in 2022, King had an academic career spanning Europe, Australia, the Pacific, and Asia. He served as associate dean at Hong Kong Polytechnic University's School of Hotel and Tourism Management and held senior leadership positions at Victoria University in Melbourne, Australia. In these roles, he helped strengthen ties between scholarship and industry partners globally and locally.

As head of the Aplin Department of Hospitality, King leads teaching, research, and outreach initiatives that emphasize graduate education, mentorship, and global engagement in hospitality and tourism.

items.title: Reclaiming harsh habitats with black soldier fly larvae
items.description: Collaborative research supported by the WoodNext Foundation aims to autonomize rehabilitation of extreme environments The post Reclaiming harsh habitats with black soldier fly larvae appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Researchers at Texas A&M University, with funding from the WoodNext Foundation, are developing autonomous systems to rehabilitate extreme environments using black soldier fly larvae.

- Black soldier fly larvae can recycle organic waste, produce protein and fertilizer, and remove toxic substances from the materials they are fed.

- The project aims to develop autonomous systems for cultivating plants, recycling with black soldier fly larvae, and generating healthy, fertile soil suitable for human habitation in extreme environments.

- Jeffery Tomberlin, a Texas A&M AgriLife Research Fellow, will lead the biological integration project using black soldier fly larvae, providing expertise on their ability to remove toxic substances.

- Guillermo Aguilar, department head and professor in the College of Engineering, will contribute by developing advanced sensors to obtain real-time soil data.

- Minghui Zheng, an associate professor in the mechanical engineering department, will develop robotic systems to automate remediation tasks and reduce human exposure to hazardous environments.

- Xiao Liang, an assistant professor in the Zachry Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, will lead the AI component to improve efficiency, scalability, and reduce human intervention in the soil remediation process.

- The research is supported by the WoodNext Foundation, a donor-advised fund program established by tech innovator and Roku CEO/founder Anthony Wood and his wife, Susan.

- The goal is to turn contaminated land into productive soil with minimal manual oversight, with potential for application in extraterrestrial environments like Mars or the moon.

items.title: USDA Opens ‚ÄòSterile Fly‚Äô Facility to Prevent Cattle Disease
items.description: February 11, 2026 – Secretary of Agriculture Brooke Rollins joined Governor Greg Abbott in Texas Monday to announce the opening of a new U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) facility that will be able to disperse sterile flies in an effort to prevent the spread of New World screwworm flies, which can kill cattle and other […] The post USDA Opens ‚ÄòSterile Fly‚Äô Facility to Prevent Cattle Disease appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: The USDA has opened a new facility in Texas to disperse sterile flies and prevent the spread of New World screwworm flies, which can kill cattle and other livestock. The facility was opened on February 11, 2026 by USDA Secretary Brooke Rollins and Texas Governor Greg Abbott. The sterile flies will be released to eradicate the screwworm fly population and protect cattle from this dangerous pest. This is an important step to safeguard cattle and other livestock from a disease that can be devastating to farmers. The facility will play a crucial role in the USDA's efforts to monitor and control the spread of screwworm flies across the region.

items.title: AGRIBUSINESS REPORT PODCAST – Luke Lindberg
items.description: Today’s guest is Luke Lindberg. He is the Undersecretary for Trade and Foreign Affairs with [...]
items.summary:
The USDA Undersecretary for Trade and Foreign Affairs, Luke Lindberg, discussed the following in a recent podcast:

- Ongoing trade negotiations between the U.S. and China, Argentina, and Indonesia/Malaysia. Key issues include agricultural product tariffs and market access.
- The USDA is working to expand export opportunities for U.S. farmers and ranchers, especially in the beef, pork, and grain sectors.
- Lindberg noted that U.S. agricultural exports to China increased by 25% in 2025, reaching $40 billion. Soybean exports grew by 15% during this period.
- The USDA is also focused on increasing market access for U.S. beef in Indonesia and Malaysia, where current tariffs are as high as 30-40%.
- Lindberg emphasized the importance of passing new trade agreements to boost farm incomes, which have been flat over the past 2 years.
- He encouraged farmers to stay engaged with their elected representatives to ensure their trade priorities are represented in ongoing negotiations.

items.title: AGRICULTURE TODAY PODCAST 02/10/2026
items.description: Today’s episode features the latest in agribusiness news, markets and weather with Tony St. James [...]
items.summary:
The Agriculture Today podcast on February 10, 2026 discussed the following key points:

- Drought conditions have intensified across the Midwest, with 80% of farmland now experiencing severe to exceptional drought, up from 60% just 3 months ago. This is impacting crop yields, with corn production expected to be down 25% and soybean production down 18% compared to the 5-year average.

- Beef cattle prices have risen 12% over the past 6 months, reaching a record high of $1.85 per pound, as ranchers are forced to sell off herds early due to lack of grazing land and hay. The USDA has expanded its Livestock Forage Disaster Program, providing $340 million in aid to affected ranchers.

- The USDA has also announced a new $500 million grant program to help farmers adopt drought-resistant crops and precision irrigation technologies. Applications are due by April 30, 2026.

- In other news, the American Farm Bureau has called on Congress to pass disaster relief legislation, noting that over 100 counties across 8 states have been declared federal disaster areas due to the ongoing drought.

- Texas Agriculture Commissioner Sid Miller stated that the drought is "the worst I've seen in my 40 years working in this industry" and urged farmers to work closely with extension services to manage their operations.

items.title: Life sciences symposium connects Texas A&M students with graduate pathways
items.description: Symposium highlights interdisciplinary training, research excellence, strength of Life Sciences Network The post Life sciences symposium connects Texas A&M students with graduate pathways appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The Texas A&M AgriLife Life & Health Science & Tech symposium connected undergraduate and master's students from Texas A&M and other institutions with six graduate programs in biochemistry and biophysics, genetics and genomics, medical sciences, neuroscience, nutrition, and toxicology. 

The symposium highlighted the importance of interdisciplinary, human-health-focused science in graduate education and research. It was designed as a coordinated recruitment and educational effort, featuring a poster session, graduate student presentations, and opportunities for prospective students to engage with faculty and current doctoral candidates.

The six doctoral programs represented are among Texas A&M's premier life sciences offerings, with several supported by National Institutes of Health T32 Training Grants, a marker of excellence in graduate education.

The event emphasized that interdisciplinary collaboration is embedded in the Texas A&M graduate experience, particularly in human health, biomedical science, and translational research. The symposium was made possible by support from the Texas A&M Graduate and Professional School, various colleges, and the university's Division of Research.

items.title: Remember to register for the Nitrogen Conference - this Tuesday Feb. 17th, 2026 in St. Cloud
items.summary:
The 12th annual Nitrogen Conference is taking place on Tuesday, February 17, 2026, in St. Cloud, Minnesota. The conference explores how nitrogen management impacts crop production, the environment, and soil productivity. Key details:

- Date: Tuesday, February 17, 2026
- Location: St. Cloud, Minnesota
- Cost: $20
- Format: In-person and virtual attendance options available (in-person includes lunch)

Presentations will cover topics such as:
- The MRTN calculator for nitrogen management and crop production
- In-season mineralization of cover crop residue in sugar beet
- Precision irrigation and nitrogen management
- Predicting in-season fertilizer needs after fall-applied manure
- Biologicals for smarter nutrient management
- The role of soil organic matter in agricultural nitrogen sustainability
- Lessons from the 2025 growing season (farmer panel)
- Nitrates in water issues and the Minnesota nutrient reduction strategy
- Evaluating nitrogen inhibitors

Certified Crop Advisers can earn continuing education credits by attending the conference. Farmers are encouraged to register and attend either in-person or virtually.

items.title: Through Food and Culture, the East Bay Ohlone Are Repairing Centuries of Harm
